Applied Machine Learning

Cornell University - CS 5785 (Open Online Version).

About Us

Machine learning is everywhere. It can be used to predict the weather, monitor stock prices, drive autonomous vehicles, and generate art. But deep down, machine learning is all about math, statistics, and code.


In this open online course, we will tell the story of machine learning. We will cover its mathematical and algorithmic foundations and also show how to implement machine learning algorithms in practice. We are thrilled that you are here! Welcome to Cornell Tech’s CS 5785 - Applied Machine Learning.


Prerequisites
  • Experience with programming with Python. (Cornell CS 1110 or equivalent)
  • Linear algebra. (Cornell MATH 2210, MATH 4310 or equivalent)
  • Statistics and probability. (Cornell STSCI 2100 or equivalent)

    • Instructors

    Volodymyr Kuleshov

    Assistant Professor


    Volodymyr Kuleshov focuses on machine learning and its applications in scientific discovery, health, and sustainability. He is also the co-founder of Afresh, a startup that uses AI to significantly driving down food waste.

     

    Nathan Kallus

    Assistant Professor


    Nathan Kallus' research interests include personalization; optimization, especially under uncertainty; causal inference; sequential decision making; credible and robust inference; and algorithmic fairness.

     

    Serge Belongie

    Professor


    Serge Belongie specializes in computer vision, machine learning, augmented reality, and human-in-the-loop computing. He is now the head of the Pioneer Centre for Artificial Intelligence at the University of Copenhagen.

     

    Hongjun Wu

    Producer


    Hongjun Wu is interested in applying machine learning techniques to optimize 3D animation and video game. He is working on automated procedural mesh and shader generation with artificial intelligence.

     

    Lecture 1: Introduction.

    In this lecture, we will talk about what this course is, what is applied machine learning, and the three approaches to Machine Learning. We will also go through the logistics.

    Supervised Learning Unsupervised Learning Reinforcement Learning
    1.1 - Introduction to Machine Learning 1.2 - Three Approaches to Machine Learning 1.3 - About the Course 1.4 - Logistics and Other Information

    ESL - Chapter 1

    Lecture 2: Anatomy of Supervised Machine Learning.

    Introduction Models Features Objectives Model training Ordinary least squares

    We will start diving into one of the approaches to machine learning, that is, Supervised Learning. We will give a general introduction about Supervised Learning, as well as define the components of a dataset and a learning algorithm.

    2.1 - A Supervised Machine Learning Problem 2.2 - The Dataset 2.3 - Learning Algorithms

    Lecture 3: Optimization and Linear Regression.

    Optimization by gradient descent Normal equations Polynomial feature expansion Extensions of linear regression

    Some calculus review, and we dive into our first optimization method, Gradient Descent. We will talk about ordinary least squares and non-linear least squares, and how they are used in machine learning algorithms.

    3.1 - Optimization and Calculus 3.2 - Gradient Descent 3.3 - Ordinary Least Squares 3.4 - Non-Linear Least Squares

    Lecture 4: Foundations of Supervised Learning.

    Data distribution Hypothesis classes Bayes optimality Over/under fitting Regularization

    You might want to ask, why does supervised learning work? That is precisely the topic we want to tackle in this lecture. We will talk about the two biggest pitfalls to machine learning, and how to deal with them using regularization.

    4.1 - The Data Distribution 4.2 - Why Does Supervised Learning Work? 4.3 - Overfitting and Underfitting 4.4 - Regularization 4.5 - L1 Regularization and Sparsity
    Lecture 4 Slides - Live Lecture 4 Slides - PDF

    ESL - Chapter 2.6-2.9, Chapter 18.

    Lecture 5: Maximum Likelihood Learning.

    Maximum likelihood learning Bayesian ML MAP Learning Example Algorithms

    We will be discussing probabilistic modeling and maximum likelihood learning in this lecture. We will explain Monte Carlo estimation, touch upon probabilistic linear regression, and define Bayesian algorithms.

    5A.1 - Probabilistic Modeling 5A.2 - Monte Carlo Estimation 5A.3 - Maximum Likelihood Learning 5A.4 - Extensions of Maximum Likelihood 5B.1 - Probabilistic Linear Regression 5B.2 - Bayesian Algorithms

    Lecture 6: Classification Algorithms.

    KNN Logistic Regression Softmax Regression

    Classification problems is one of the fundamentals of machine learning. We will discuss nearest neighbors and logistic regression, as well as softmax regression, which are all handy tools when solving classification problems.

    6.1 - Classification 6.2 - Nearest Neighbors 6.3 - Non-Parametric Models 6.4 - Logistic Regression 6.5 - Softmax Regression

    Lecture 7: Generative Algorithms.

    Generative models Gaussian Discriminant Analysis

    We will discuss the difference between discriminative models and generative models, what generative models are, what can they do, and define Gaussian discriminant analysis.

    7.1 - Generative Models 7.2 - Gaussian Discriminant Analysis 7.3 - Gaussian Discriminant Analysis (Learning)

    Lecture 8: Naive Bayes.

    Naive Bayes Bag of Words Generative vs. Discriminative Methods

    Naive Bayes is a simple and popular classification algorithm. We will go over the mechanics of Naive Bayes as well as how to apply it to text classification.

    8.1 - Text Classification 8.2 - Naive Bayes 8.3 - Naive Bayes (Learning)
    Lecture 8 Slides - Live Lecture 8 Slides - PDF

    Lecture 9: Support Vector Machines.

    SVM Margins Max-margin Classifiers Hinge Loss Sub-gradient Descent

    Support vector machines are one of the most robust prediction methods in machine learning. We will go over margins, loss, as well as optimization for SVMs.

    9.1 - Classification Margins 9.2 - The Max-Margin Classifier 9.3 - Soft Margins and the Hinge Loss 9.4 - Optimization for SVMs
    Lecture 9 Slides - Live Lecture 9 Slides - PDF

    Lecture 10: Dual Formulation of Support Vector Machines.

    Lagrange Duality Dual Formulation of SVM SMO algorithm

    We will dive deeper into support vector machines by introducing Lagrange duality, and define the dual form of support vector machines.

    10.1 - Lagrange Duality 10.2 - Dual Formulation of SVMs 10.3 - More on SVM Duals

    Lecture 11: Kernels.

    Kernels Mercer's Theorem RBF Kernels

    In this lecture, we will explain what Kernels mean in machine learning, we will provide examples, as well as how to apply the kernel trick in support vector machines.

    11.1 - The Kernel Trick (Intuition) 11.2 - The Kernel Trick (Example) 11.3 - The Kernel Trick in SVMs 11.4 - Types of Kernels
    Lecture 11 Slides - Live Lecture 11 Slides - PDF

    Lecture 12: Decision Trees.

    Bagging Ensembling CART

    Decision trees are simple and interpretable algorithms for regression and classification. We will talk about what they are, how to use them, as well as bagging and random forests to improve the performance of decision tree models.

    12.1 - Decision Trees 12.2 - Learning Decision Trees 12.3 - Bagging 12.4 - Random Forests

    Lecture 13: Boosting.

    Adaboost Gradient Boosting

    Boosting helps a weak learner to become better. In this lecture, we will talk about the essence of boosting, additive models, as well as gradient boosting.

    13.1 - Boosting and Ensembling 13.2 - Additive Models 13.3 - Gradient Boosting

    Lecture 14: Neural Networks.

    NN Perceptrons Multi-layer Neural Networks

    Neural networks are machine learning models inspired by the brain. In this lecture, we will give an introduction of neural networks, how perception mimic human neurons, and back propagation.

    14.1 - An Artificial Neuron 14.2 - Artificial Neural Networks 14.3 - Backpropagation

    DL Convolutional neural networks Applications

    We will provide a brief introduction to deep learning. After an introduction of convolutions, we will introduce convolutional neural networks, one of the very important topics in machine learning.

    15.1 - What is Deep Learning? 15.2 - Convolutions 15.3 - Convolutional Neural Networks

    Lecture 17: Density Estimation.

    Density Estimation Probabilistic Models K-Nearest Neighbors

    Density estimation is an important tools in unsupervised machine learning. We will also discuss kernel density estimation, as well as latent variable models.

    17.1 - Unsupervised Probabilistic Models 17.2 - Kernel Density Estimation 17.3 - Latent Variable Models

    Lecture 18: Clustering.

    Clustering K-means Expectation-Maximization

    Clustering is perhaps the most popular class of unsupervised learning algorithms. We will introduce gaussian mixture models, expectation maximization, as well as generalization in probabilistic models.

    18.1 - Gaussian Mixture Models 18.2 - Expectation Maximization 18.3 - Expectation Maximization in Gaussian Mixture Models 18.4 - Generalization in Probabilistic Models

    Lecture 19: Dimensionality Reduction.

    Dimensionality Reduction PCA ICA

    Note: Lecture video 19 part 2 was incorrectly titled as part 3 on Youtube.

    Reducing the dimensionality of the data can help us better interpret it and also make learning algorithms more efficient. To do that, the most used method is principal component analysis, or PCA.

    19.1 - What is Dimensionality Reduction? 19.2 - Principal Component Analysis

    Evaluation Dataset Splits Cross-Validation Performance Measures

    So, now you have a model. How to evaluate it? We will talk about the ML development workflow, and how to evaluate classification and regression models.

    Lecture 21: Model Iteration and Improvement.

    Diagnosis Model Iteration Process Bias/Variance Tradeoff Baselines Learning Curves

    Developing machine learning models is an iterative process. We will encounter difficulties and errors, and it is part of our job to fix them. We will talk about error and bias/variance analysis.

    21.1 - Error Analysis 21.2 - Bias / Variance Analysis 21.3 - Baselines

    Diagnosis Error Analysis Data Integrity Human-Level Performance
